explanation: You must know whether any of the called identifiers are macros (or otherwise expand inline) that could assign to or otherwise modify the function parameters (param, next_param) when expanded inside process_short_param. If a callee is a normal function, it cannot reassign the caller's parameter variables (arguments are passed by value), but a macro can expand into code that directly assigns to param or next_param. Therefore the definitions (or at least the preprocessor/function declarations) of all process_param__* symbols called from this function are required to determine whether any macro expansion in this function modifies its parameters. In particular, process_param__threads, process_param__connections and process_param__timeout are called with param+1 and next_param (next_param is an lvalue) so their macro definitions must be checked for direct assignment to next_param or use of the identifier param. The remaining process_param__* symbols are called with string literals but could still be macros that reference or assign the local parameter names (param/next_param) when expanded; their definitions must therefore be examined as well. Also include fprintf (could be a macro on some platforms) to ensure its expansion does not modify parameters, and PERF_RPL_PARAM_ERROR (if a macro) to ensure its expansion has no side effects on parameters. Checking these symbols' definitions is sufficient to decide whether process_short_param itself (after macro expansion) modifies any of its parameters.
